conclusion: To determine when Object A and Object B are farthest apart, analyze the velocity-time graph.

The graph shows the velocity of both objects as a function of time. Object A has a linearly decreasing velocity starting from v0 and reaching zero at t2. Object B has a complex velocity profile, starting from zero, increasing, peaking, and then decreasing.
When the velocities of the two objects are equal, the distance between them stops increasing or decreasing momentarily.
Find points where the slopes of the velocity curves are equal, indicating the same acceleration.
At t1, Object A has a higher velocity than Object B, and Object B is still accelerating.
From t1 to t2, Object A slows down while Object B accelerates and then decelerates.
At t2, Object A comes to a stop, but Object B continues with some velocity.
After t2, Object B slows down but still has positive velocity until it matches the slope of Object A's curve again.
The graphs show that the tangents match again around t3, indicating that after this point, the distance between them starts to decrease.
The farthest apart moment occurs when the relative distance is maximized, just before their velocities become equal again after t2.
The moment when the two objects are farthest apart is at t = t3.
